titleStmt.title: Correspondence of Catherine the Great - placeography

place.note: Known as Bad Arolsen since 1997
A city in central Crimea.
An Ottoman territory ruled by the Habsburgs from 1716. Invaded by the Ottomans in 1788.
Now the Republic of Bashkortostan, within the Russian Federation
Today the capital of Serbia.
City in the Crimea. Before 1944 was known as Qarasuvbazar. Catherine calls it Карасу-Базар.

Located in the Dnieper/Bug Estuary in the Black Sea. Taken by the Russians on 7 November 1788, in Catherine's Second Russo-Turkish War.

Historically part of Moldavia. Southern part was also spread over present-day Romania

A key natural boundary disputed during both Russo-Turkish Wars of Catherine's reign, 1768-1774 and 1787-1792.

place.note: In classical mythology, the home of heroes and virtuous individuals in the underworld.
Seat of the Prince-Bishopric of Lübeck. Catherine first met her future husband Peter III, then Karl Peter Ulrich of Holstein-Gottorp, in the castle at Eutin when the pair were 10 and 11 years old.
Located in the territory of Moldavia
The largest port town on the Danube river (Wikipedia).
Small kingdom in Central-Eastern Europe. Included territories of Poland as well.
Area in the Vasileostrovsky District in Saint-Petersburg

place.note: The object of Catherine's famous 'Greek Project', which aimed to take Greece from Ottoman control and, ideally, to set Catherine's grandson Constantine upon the throne of a separate empire at Constantinople. The inspiration for this project came from several sources, including the Neoclassical obsession with Greece that was raging across Europe and Russia's particular historical ties with Byzantine culture, especially via the Russian Orthodox Church and the symbolism of tsarist power.

Imperial free city of the Holy Roman Empire, member of the Hanseatic League. Catherine visited repeatedly in her childhood to see her maternal grandmother. Home of Catherine's correspondent Mme Bielke. At the end of her reign, Catherine appointed Friedrich Melchior grimm Russian envoy in Hamburg.

event.label: Hanover officially became an electorate in the Holy Roman Empire
Accession of the elector of Hanover to the British throne as George I, in accordance with the Act of Settlement of 1701. Beginning of the Personal Union between Hannover and Great Britain.
Became the kingdom of Hanover followig occupation by Napoleonic France.
End of the Personal Union when Queen Victoria inherited the British throne. Her uncle Ernest Augustus inherited Hannover, as Hanoverian crown was required to pass to any surviving males.

place.bibl: Michael Fry, 'Hanover', in Britain in the Hanoverian Age, 1714-1837: An Encyclopedia, ed. by Gerald Newman and Leslie Ellen Brown (New York and London: Garland, 1997), p. 314.
The Hanoverian Dimension in British History, 1714-1837, ed. by Brendan Simms and Torsten Riotte (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2007)
place.note: Home of Catherine's correspondent Johann Georg Zimmermann.
Town on the largest island in Denmark Själland

When Catherine refers to her 'Hermitage', it is generally a metonymic allusion to the circle of intimates who enjoyed an informal, salon-like atmosphere and attended the plays performed at the Hermitage Theatre, often for audiences of only 10 or so guests personally selected by the empress. Catherine had a series of rules for behaviour in her Hermitage, designed to create a polite and jovial tone. It included points such as 'do not gnaw on anything' and 'join in all innocent fun'. The punishment for an infraction was to drink a cold glass of water and read aloud from Trediakovsky's 'Tilemakhida' (a verse translation of Fénélon's 'Télémaque'); further offences meant that one had to learn three lines of the 'Tilemakhida' by heart. Part of the Winter Palace complex.
Village in the vicinity of Kotka

Today one of the two centres of the city of Kotka (the other is Karhula). Located at the mouth of the Kymi River.
Founded by Peter I, a fortified island port in St. Petersburg and the base of the Russian Baltic fleet.
Island in the Gulf of Finland. Village now located in the city of Kotka.
Small village on the coast of Finland. Now part of Kotka.
In Finland, according to letter 58. Wikipedia suggests this may be Karinainen.

Port city on the west coast of Tuscany

A small river in Moldova. The area between the Malaya and Bolshaya Salcha Rivers was the site of multiple clashes between the Russians and the Turks in August-September 1789.
A commune of five villages, and the name of one of those villages, in Braila county, Romania. Breve accent over a in Romanian. (Wikipedia)
Seat of the dukes of Württemberg, home of the parents of Grand Duchess Mariya Fedorovna, wife of the future Paul I.
The provincial seat was Moscow.
A city and a region in Turkey.

A former township in Nikolaevskaia Oblast' (Ukraine) that grew from a small protective fortification at the border of three states. Became of particular interest of the Russian army in the mid-18th century; was named Ol'viopol' after an ancient Greek settlement; expanded from a garrison to a provincial town by 1797. The 19th and the beginning of the 20th centuries were associated with the development of small enterprises, the Jewish ghetto, and pogroms. In 1920, became a part of the newly founded Soviet city Pervomaisk.

place.bibl: St. Petersburg, 1703-1825, ed. by Anthony Cross (Basingstoke: Palgrave Macmillan, 2003)
M.A. Gordin, Byloi Peterburg: Ekaterininskii vek (St. Petersburg: Pushkinskii fond, 2004)
Catriona Kelly, St. Petersburg: Shadows of the Past (New Haven: Yale University Press, 2014)
George E. Munro, The Most Intentional City: St. Petersburg in the Reign of Catherine the Great (Madison, N.J.:Fairleigh Dickinson University Press, 2008)
place.note: Capital of Russia under Catherine II, founded by Peter I in 1703.

A palace complex begun by Peter I on the Gulf of Finland near St. Petersburg. Catherine regularly celebrated the anniversary of her accession to the throne at Peterhof, since it was from there that she departed for St. Petersburg on the day of her coup, 28 June/9 July 1762. Nonetheless, she referred to the palace as 'haïssable Péterhof, que je ne puis souffrir' (letter to Mme Bielke of 25 June 1772, SIRIO, xiii, p. 259). She explained her aversion in a letter to Prince Henry of Prussia from about the same time, 3/12 July 1772: bad memories ('j'y ai vu dans ma vie tant de vilaines choses que l'idée s'en retrace dans mon esprit chaque fois que j'y viens') and objections to the style of the gardens and fountains ('ces détestables fontaines, qui donnent la torture à l''eau pour lui faire prendre un cours opposé à celui de la nature') (Briefwechsel zwischen Heinrich Prinz von Preußen und Katharina II. von Russland, p. 93).

The agreed-upon boundary of Austria's acquisition in the First Partition of Poland. The Austrians argued that the border should be extended to the Zbruch. There was and remains some confusion as to the names of these rivers, as the Austrians claimed that the Podhorze did not exist and that they therefore should own the former Polish territory up to the Zbruch.

Early in her reign, in 1764, Catherine placed her former lover Stanislas August Poniatowski on the throne of Poland. After the first two partitions of Poland in 1772-1773 and 1793, the Polish Commonwealth ceased to exist with the Third Partition of 1795, to be reinstated only in 1918. It is frequently called 'la république' in Catherine's letters: its form of government, the subject of many power struggles during Catherine's reign, consisted of an elected king and a Sejm or parliament, in which each of the deputies had the right to veto any laws passed (the 'liberum veto').
Home of Henry, prince of Prussia, near Berlin.
Located on the right bank of the Danube
Estonian island in the Baltic Sea, previously known as Ösel in German and Swedish

place.placeName: Church of Saint Louis of the French, Moscow
Церковь Святого Людовика Французского в Москве
place.note: In August 1789, all members of the French colony in Moscow were invited to a meeting at which they resolved to 'former une communauté particulière et d'élever une église où le culte catholique pût se célébrer selon les rites de sa nation, en vertu des traités entre la France et la Russie' ('to form a separate comunnity and to build a church where Catholic worship might be held according to the rites of their nation, in accordance with the treaties between France and Russia'). A building was purchased on Lubyanka Street in Stretenka district: the current church of St. Louis is still located there. The church was consecrated on 30 March 1791, 'en présence de la colonie française et avec la participation de la noblesse russe' ('in the presence of the French colony and with the participation of the Russian nobility'). The church's first priest was abbé Pesme de Matignicourt, who in 1793 was expelled from Russia for refusing to swear an oath of loyalty to the French royalty. Catherine required that all French ctiziens swear this oath in the church, where they kissed the cross and received their documents to remain in Russia. (Vladislav Rjétoutski, 'La communauté francophone de Moscou sous le règne de Catherine II', pp. 460-61; 'La colonie française et l'église catholique de Moscou à la fin du XVIIIe siècle').
German settlement on the Volga, now a district of Volgograd.
A city in the southwestern region of the Crimean Peninsula.
Place of death of admiral Richard Kempenfelt in 1782
Inhabited sea fortress built on six islands. It is now part of Helsinki.

place.bibl: Dimitri Shvidkovsky, The Empress and the Architect: British Architecture and Gardens at the Court of Catherine the Great (New Haven and London: Yale University Press, 1996), especially pp. 41-116.
Official site of Tsarskoe Selo State Museum.
place.note: A country palace residence outside St. Petersburg, today located in the town of Pushkin. It was first developed by Catherine I, to whom Peter I gave the estate in 1710. Architect Bartolomeo Rastrelli was responsible for the Baroque Catherine Palace. It was Catherine II's preferred residence, and the court regularly spent the summer there. Catherine commissioned from architect Charles Cameron Roman-style baths (1779-1792) and the Cameron Gallery (1787), which housed busts of the great men of classical antiquity, as well as those of more recent heroes like Russian poet Mikhail Lomonosov and British politician Charles James Fox. Cameron also redesigned the interiors of the Catherine palace, including the Green Dining Room, the Chinese Blue Drawing room, the Grand Ducal Bedchamber. For Catherine's apartments, Cameron designed the Arabesque Hall, the Lyons Hall, the Chinese Hall, the Domed Dining Room, and Catherine's bedchamber. Catherine devoted particular attention to the gardens, where she commissioned a series of allegorical monuments representing her successes and dreams of international victories. Tsarskoe Selo later housed the Lyceum attended by the poet Aleksandr Pushkin, whose poetry celebrated its gardens. It is now located in the town of Pushkin.
Today Volgograd (formerly Stalingrad).
River that gave Tsaritsyn its name. Confluent of the Volga.
Town on the right bank of the Danube.
Formerly Simbirsk.
Known in Russian as the Yaik/Jaik before 1775.

Apparently in Swedish Finland, according to letters 58 and 91. Mikhelson entered Swedish Finland by this route in May 1789.
Home of the Imperial Chamber Court (Reichskammergericht), one of the two highest courts of the Holy Roman Empire.
Baltic port town, member of the Hanseatic League, a Swedish possession during Catherine's reign.

Foreign ambassadors were regularly imprisoned there when hostilities opened between the Ottoman Empire and their respective courts. Catherine's ambassadors Aleksei Mikhailovich Obreskov and Yakov Ivanovich Bulgakov were imprisoned there.

A village in Novgorod region. It used to be a large iam (ям) on the route between Novgorod and Pleskov (Pskov) – the point of postal and supply system that was established by the Mongols in the 13th century and preserved in Tsarist Russia until the 20 century. Like inns in Europe, the yams provided lodging for travellers and accommodation for horses.
Was part of Wallachia; became part of Russian Empire in 1774.
Was the administrative centre of Alexey Orlov's military expedition; the place of the fleet truce on 2 (14) july 1772.
was a principality within the Holy Roman Empire. It was located some 50 km east of Cologne, and contained the modern localities of Freudenberg, Hilchenbach, Kreuztal, Siegen, and Wilnsdorf. (Wiki)

A vanished village on the left bank of the river Dnepr. Founded in 1631; developed as a defensive fortress until the mid-18th century; affiliated with the Ekaterinoslav Viceroyalty in 1783-96; submerged by the Kamianske reservoir, Dnipropetrovsk Oblast', in 1963-1965.

A town located 35 km north of Mogilev in contemporary Belarus. It belonged to the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth but became a part of the Russian empire after the first partition in 1772
Town near Saint Petersburg

A former military fort located in the Sudetes mountain range. The history of the place refers to the rise of the Kingdom of Prussia and the fall of Polish Prussia, that ended up with the partition of Poland by the Kingdom of Prussia, Russian Empire and Habsburg Austria. The fort was constructed in 1765–77 when this part of the Sudetes belonged to the Kingdom of Prussia. In the 1938, the Sudetes became a pretext for the annexation of the First Czechoslovak Republic by Nazi German; Poland and Hungary also occupied "back" some of the territories.
Monastery in Moscow, founded in 14th cent.

the Maison royale de Saint-Louis, at St Cyr to the west of Paris, was a boarding school for girls opened by Louis XIV’s second wife, Madame de Maintenon, in 1686; it served as a model for educational institutions for girls across Europe.
